title: 111_hr4810
content: The "End Veteran Homelessness Act of 2010" increases funding for comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans to $200,000,000 in fiscal year 2010. It also improves payments for providing services to homeless veterans. The "End Veteran Homelessness Act of 2010" increases funding for homeless veterans' services to $200,000,000 in fiscal year 2010 and enhances payment adjustments for service provision. The "End Veteran Homelessness Act of 2010" increases funding for homeless veterans' services to $200,000,000 in fiscal year 2010 and enhances payment adjustments for service provision by considering other sources of income for grant recipients. The "End Veteran Homelessness Act of 2010" increases funding for homeless veterans' services to $200,000,000 in fiscal year 2010 and requires grant recipients to provide expenditure statements quarterly to the Secretary. Grant recipients must repay any unused funds at the end of each quarter. The Secretary will make additional payments to grant recipients if the amount spent in a calendar quarter exceeds the amount provided, as long as the total annual payment does not exceed the recipient's annual amount. Payments can be used to match other grants. Clerical amendments are made to the section heading. The section heading and subsection heading for payments for furnishing services to homeless veterans are amended. The table of sections is also updated to reflect these changes. In 2012, payments were made for furnishing services to homeless veterans. Section 4 focuses on supported housing program outreach. Section 2024 of title 38, United States Code, requires each medical center to employ specialists for landlord outreach in the supported housing program for veterans. Specialists facilitate landlord participation and resolve housing issues for veterans in the program. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is tasked with mediating disputes between veterans and landlords in housing assistance programs. They also work with HUD to provide homeless veterans access to the Homelessness Prevention and Rapid Re-Housing Program for essentials like security deposits and rent payments. Authorization of appropriations for a Department of Veterans Affairs program to provide financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing is amended to allocate specific amounts for fiscal years. Additionally, there is a promotion of awareness of VA programs to assist homeless veterans, especially homeless women veterans and homeless veterans with children. Section 532 of title 38, United States Code, amended to promote awareness of assistance for homeless veterans, with a focus on homeless women veterans and veterans with children. Passed by the House of Representatives on March 22, 2010.
